item.description: Tuesday, June 1, 10:51 AM Mildly nostalgia inducing piece about why Wordstar was the perfect word processor for creative writers. I feel like the argument about the advantages of being a modal editor probably also carries over the the classic text editors like vi(m) or even emacs. https://www.sfwriter.com/wordstar.htm Tuesday, June 1, 10:54 AM Confirmation bias read on how connections and social circle emphasize memes about certain class of people being more capable than others when in reality good fortune and being at the right place is what’s most important.

Sunday, May 30, 3:11 PM The only fiction I’ve read in the past year or two is science fiction (with the exception of an odd Jack Reacher novel). The idea of writing science fiction itself is intriguing and is the source of some fantasizing on my part. Will probably check out Orson Scott Card’s “How to Write Science Fiction and Fantasy” as referenced by this essay sometime. https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/JZ9czc5CCX39wsviM/how-to-write-science-fiction-and-fantasy-a-short-summary Sunday, May 30, 3:37 PM

Saturday, May 29, 11:58 AM Absolutely bonkers report about how flash cards used by US soldiers guarding sensitive spots ended up as an opsec disaster. I vaguely remember reading reports that fitness bands and running apps(like Runkeeper and Strava) ended up inadvertently revealing unmarked military bases because people noticed public running data that indicated people running in circles in the middle of the desert where official maps say there is nothing.

Friday, May 28, 1:02 AM Write up that chronicles India’s slow motion train-wreck with its indigenously developed Covid vaccine which uses the same inactivated virus tech as the Chinese vaccines. Another related but interesting point I keep encountering when looking into Covid vaccines is that, logically the inactivated vaccines are the ones one would expect to hold up well against variants, as opposed to mRNA/Adenovirus vector based vaccines that are more preoccupied with Covid-19’s spike protein than the virus itself.

Thursday, May 27, 11:41 AM Interesting interview and idea regarding mindsets (scout vs soldier). Basic premise seems to be that the soldier mindset is obsessed with changing or attacking or defending beliefs and situations (assumed to be for the better), where as the scout mindset is centered around consciously trying to build a better “map” or with seeing things as they are instead of attacking or defending. I think I will buy her book “The Scout Mindset: Why Some People See Things Clearly and Others Don’t” and give it a read, premise sounds interesting.

Wednesday, May 26, 7:14 PM Today’s Astrazeneca opt-in rollout across Malaysia seemed like it was a crap fest. I think there were fundamental mistakes made in how the entire booking portal was architected. The form design itself was decent enough (except for Google’s captcha that has a very English speaker/American bias). Honestly, there was no reason to make this so complicated, I wish they had just made the opt-in a profile level setting in mysejahtera and should have just used that data to prioritize in the same old fashion.

Tuesday, May 25, 8:46 PM Interesting article that talks about how Israel, by having the perfect band-aid/painkiller has stopped prioritizing solving the real problem that’s driving the need for the band-aid/painkiller in the first place. https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2021/05/iron-dome-israel-netanyahu-hamas/618973/?utm_source=feed Tuesday, May 25, 9:48 PM Argument that there is a cover-up of sorts happening about the effectiveness of Ivermectic as a treatment for COVID-19. What makes me skeptical is that all reports that support the drug cite India as a testing ground, but as far as I can tell, only one or two states have started trying it out.

item.title: Book Recap : Talking to Strangers
item.description: This is the second Malcolm Gladwell book I’ve read so far. I read Outliers nearly a decade ago and thought that, while it certainly was an interesting read, it didn’t personally contain any ground-breaking insight as far as I was concerned. At the risk of sounding reductionist, I thought the conclusion that success, while often (mis)attributed to talent is always backed up by time invested by the person involved, was sort of a given.

item.title: Book Recap : Samsung Rising
item.description: Finding out more about the origin stories of successful companies is always an informative and entertaining endeavor. For me that list so far includes .. Game Over, Press Start to Continue about Nintendo iWoz: Computer Geek to Cult Icon: How I Invented the Personal Computer, Co-Founded Apple, and Had Fun Doing It about Apple Masters of Doom about id Software Showstopper! the Breakneck Race to Create Windows NT and the Next Generation at Microsoft about Microsoft The latest addition to the above list is Samsung Rising by Geoffrey Cain which chronicles Samsung’s rise from an agricultural company to something more akin to The Umbrella Corporation.
